On Fri, 22 Nov 2002, Chermside, Michael wrote:
> > We coded up a TestSuite that finds all the tests in the project (which is
> > pretty fast because they all start with "_" so we don't have to use
> > "instanceof" to figure out if they are tests or not) and executes them.
> >
> > We also threw in some fun options like only running tests in certain
> > packages and running the tests in order of their execution speed (we have
> > some really slow tests, which I know is bad, but there's not too much we
> > can do about it).
> >
> > It can also run just those tests that have been compiled in the last 10
> > minutes plus tests for any classes that have been compiled in the last 10
> > minutes. (So if you modify method A.foo() and class B calls A.foo(), then
> > _ATest and _BTest will be executed.) This is to get around the problem of
> > our test suite being really slow, which is something that I want to fix
> > but cannot (for non-technical reasons).
>
> WOW!!! That sounds much better than the other utilities I've been
> able to find for this, and certainly more feature-rich than I'd have
> time to write myself. Any chance that the TestSuite you write would
> be available?

I wouldn't be able to release the code I wrote for two reasons: it's
probably copyrighted by my company, and it uses a lot of utility class
code from my project (for preferences, files, strings, file lists, etc.).

However, I'd be happy to make a new project on SourceForge or something
and create a version that isn't dependent on other code, especially if
other people are interested in helping out.

I have to warn you that my design is probably all wrong because I don't
really understand the JUnit architecture yet. I probably should have
created a TestCollector or something, but instead I created a subclass of
TestSuite that builds the list of TestCases and returns them by overriding
the testAt() and tests() methods.


Erik
